Award.AwardTitle: Scanning Electrochemical Microscopy and Ultramicroelectrode Studies of the Electrochemistry of Single Molecules and Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Allen J. Bard of the University of Texas at Austin is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Chemistry Division to study electrode reactions of single nanoparticles (with dimensions down to 4 nm, or about 1/250th of the diameter of a human hair). These studies utilize very small (ultramicro) electrodes as well as the technique of scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) that was developed in the Bard laboratories. The central aims of this project are to develop techniques to characterize nanoparticles and to establish a new stochastic approach to study electrochemical reactions.
Such studies will be of value in understanding the electrocatalytic properties of materials, important in energy conversion devices (e.g. fuel cells and solar energy systems), and could provide the basis of analysis at the single molecule or very low concentration level. These would be useful, for example, in the detection of chemical and biological warfare (CB) agents or biological species that are present in blood at currently undetectable levels. Students and postdoctoral fellows will be trained in advanced electrochemical techniques with relevance to energy research, electrosynthesis and electroanalysis. Through the Center for Electrochemistry (CEC) at UT, a number of outreach activities are pursued, e.g. software exchange via the CEC website, an annual conference heavily attended by students and post doctoral fellows, periodic chalk talks by UT or visiting faculty, and training of visitors in SECM at the CEC electrochemical instrumentation facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For most of history, and still generally today, when chemists make measurements, they analyze ensembles of huge numbers of molecules or particles. That is, they measure some kind of average behavior of many particles all at once.  A particle could be anything from a metallic nanoparticle of a molecule to a virus. In that kind of measurement, any individual peculiarities between particles are not seen. However, in the past three decades, scientists have begun to devise experiments that are beginning to give insight into how the world of single molecules or single nanoparticles can be very different from the world of ensembles.

 

These are experiments where the action takes place in very small spaces, where sizes are measured in nanometers. A nanometer is still pretty large compared to the size of atoms or small molecules like water, but to get an idea of just how small it is, try to imagine 1/100,000 of the thickness of a piece of paper—about one nanometer. Obviously, objects this tiny are challenging to study and manipulate, but scientists have been interested in studying nanometer-sized objects because when a material is in the form of particles that small it can behave very differently from the bulk material, especially in terms of chemical reactivity or properties effected by surface area. Techniques have been developed to analyze and manipulate the nano-world, which is the basis of nanotechnology and nanoscience.

 

The goal of our research has been to extend the analysis of small objects to include electrochemistry of single molecules and single nanoparticles, including development of the methods and analytical tools, and application to important chemical problems. In our recent NSF work we have particularly focused on soft, insulating particles, such as emulsion droplets, vesicles, viruses, and large biological molecules. For example, we studied tiny individual droplets of an emulsion as they collided with a small conductive surface. To be able to specifically detect individual events, we coupled these collisions with a splash of light by ensuring that the electrochemistry that occurs when the droplet hits the conductive surface produces light. This is one way that electrochemistry provides new tools and insights in this field. We also expanded the versatility of the methods by studying other oil-in-water emulsion systems and analyzing biologically relevant molecules trapped inside these oil droplets.

 

This research has provided excellent opportunities for the training of young chemists who have participated in hands-on, multidisciplinary research. The work has been closely associated with the Center for Electrochemistry, which has provided a curriculum in electrochemistry, visiting scientists, seminars, a dedicated electrochemical instrumentation lab with training, and an annual conference and workshop on electrochemistry.
